ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Indeed. People over here are not the first ones to notice that :-). To make a difference, you should submit feedback to the HTML WG. Best regards, Julian

From: Julian Reschke <julian.reschke@...>
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Is HTML5 cache a useless regression?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=40455398; y=V4iO8_aiel0NgTYAFl7e1NJ8iv_S228aZGO2l5Y7_v3O5gZ2tTZGFmY

On 2012-03-21 16:37, Sebastien Lambla wrote:
> Those are orthogonal concern. The manifest defines which of the assets
> ought to be made available offline, aka persisted in the cache for a
> duration that is not tied to the duration of the max-age but of the
> installed app. *That said*, the behavior in deciding to do a conditional
> request or not based on existing caching validation function would make
> a lot of sense.
>
> More so, it makes a lot of sense for an app that can be used both
> offline and online to have the caching semantics sematics of resources
> being present and respected, for until a user "installs" the app, the
> app will react like any HTTP application.
>
> For me, appCache can (and probably ought to) simply extend and override
> the semantics of caching controls to ensure that whatever caching
> sematics, the cached (and maybe stale) resource state is available for
> however long the application is installed.
> ...

Indeed. People over here are not the first ones to notice that :-).

To make a difference, you should submit feedback to the HTML WG.

Best regards, Julian
